question: Is there an FAQ for this Machine Learning course?

answer_llm:
Based on the FAQ:

- The course has an original GitHub repository (the original course repo).
- You can create your own GitHub repository for the course (notes, homework, projects, etc.).
- You should fork the original course repo and add a link to your notes in your own repo under the Community Notes section, then create a pull request to sync with the original repo.
- For grading, you must provide the URL to your repository (the one containing your submission).

The FAQ does not mention a separate “sign-up link” repository.

answer_llm:
Based on the FAQ, questions and answers are organized in a simple, sectioned Q&A format:

- Sections/categories are used (e.g., General course-related questions, Miscellaneous).
- Each entry has:
  - Question: the exact user-facing question.
  - Answer: a concise response, sometimes with steps, links, or attribution.

Examples of the structure you can mirror:
- Section: General course-related questions
  - Question: How long is the course?
  - Answer: Approximately 4 months, but may take more if you want to do some extra activities (an extra project, an article, etc)

- Section: General course-related questions
  - Question: I just joined. What should I do next? How can I access course materials?
  - Answer: Welcome to the course! Go to the course page (http://mlzoomcamp.com/), scroll down and start going through the course materials. Then read everything in the cohort folder for your cohort’s year. Click on the links and start watching the videos. Also watch office hours from previous cohorts. Go to DTC YouTube channel and click on Playlists and search for {course yyyy}. ML Zoomcamp was first launched in 2021. Or you can just use this link: http://mlzoomcamp.com/#syllabus

- Section: Miscellaneous
  - Question: Do you pass a project based on the average of everyone else’s scores or based on the total score you earn?
  - Answer: Alexey Grigorev: “It’s based on all the scores to make sure most of you pass.”

How you can structure your own questions and answers similarly:
- Put the question under a relevant section.
- Keep the answer concise and provide concrete details, steps, or links when helpful.
- If an answer is attributed, include the attribution (e.g., name) as shown.

answer_llm: Very little theoretical content. The course covers theory only at the intuitive level (bare minimum) and emphasizes practice. For example, we won’t derive the gradient update rule for logistic regression, but we’ll cover how to use logistic regression and interpret its results.
answer_orig:
The bare minimum. The focus is more on practice, and we'll cover the theory only on the intuitive level.: https://mlbookcamp.com/article/python
For example, we won't derive the gradient update rule for logistic regression (there are other great courses for that), but we'll cover how to use logistic regression and make sense of the results.
question: How much theoretical content is there in the course?

answer_llm: No. Prior math knowledge isn’t required. The course will cover some linear algebra, but there are very few formulas and mostly code. If you want a refresher, you can watch these videos in advance: ML Zoomcamp 1.8 – Linear Algebra Refresher and the 3Blue1Brown “Vectors” chapter. And don’t hesitate to ask the community for help if you have questions.
answer_orig:
Yes! We'll cover some linear algebra in the course, but in general, there will be very few formulas, mostly code.
Here are some interesting videos covering linear algebra that you can already watch: ML Zoomcamp 1.8 - Linear Algebra Refresher from Alexey Grigorev or the excellent playlist from 3Blue1Brown Vectors | Chapter 1, Essence of linear algebra. Never hesitate to ask the community for help if you have any question.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)

- To earn a certificate, you must submit 2 out of the 3 course projects and review 3 peers’ projects by the deadline.

question: How can I earn a certificate in this course?

answer_llm:
- Complete at least 2 of the 3 course projects.
- Review at least 3 of your peers’ projects (three peer reviews) by the deadline.

If you meet both conditions, you will receive the course certificate. You can join late and still be eligible as long as you achieve two projects completed and three peer reviews by the deadline.

answer_llm:
Yes. It’s possible to receive the certificate even if you miss the midterm project, as long as you:

- finish at least two out of three projects, and
- review at least three peers’ projects for each submission by the deadline.

According to the course coordinator, only two projects are needed to get the certificate (provided you also peer-review the required number of projects).

question: Will I receive a certificate if I don't complete the midterm project?

answer_llm:
Yes. You can still graduate (receive a certificate) without submitting the midterm project as long as you:

- Submit 2 out of the 3 course projects (i.e., complete two other projects), and
- Review 3 peers’ projects by the deadline.

Midterms and capstones are solo projects, and you can still be eligible even if you join late as long as you meet the two-project and three-peer-review requirements.
answer_orig: Yes, it's possible. See the previous answer.

answer_llm:
- You should know the following Python basics:
  - How to run a Jupyter notebook
  - How to import libraries (and what libraries are)
  - How to declare a variable (and what variables are)
  - Some important data-analysis operations

- For these basics, you can follow the OpenClassrooms course “Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis” (free). If you know everything in the linked article, you’re set; otherwise read the article and consider the Introduction to Python course as well.
answer_orig:
Check this article. If you know everything in this article, you know enough. If you don’t, read the article and join the coursIntroduction to Pythone too :)
Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp
You can follow this English course from the OpenClassrooms e-learning platform, which is free and covers the python basics for data analysis: Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis - OpenClassrooms . It is important to know some basics such as: how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries (and what libraries are), how to declare a variable (and what variables are) and some important operations regarding data analysis.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)
question: What Python basics are required for this course?

answer_llm:
- Read the article mentioned in the FAQ under “How much Python should I know?” If you know everything in that article, you’re set; otherwise read it and join the Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp.

question: Where can I learn the necessary Python knowledge for this course?

answer_llm:
- Your midterm project will be reviewed by peers who cross-check that the training process works on someone else’s system, using a Python file (train.py) that should be included in the environment. Knowing how to run a notebook helps you develop and verify that code before sharing it.
- In real life, training is typically done by running a Python script rather than a notebook, so being able to run and test notebooks is part of preparing a runnable, shareable workflow.
- There can be environment issues when launching notebooks; for example, an ImportError related to jinja2 can occur, and a fix is to upgrade nbconvert. Being able to run notebooks lets you troubleshoot these kinds of problems.
- Practical tips from the material also note simple workarounds in notebook commands (e.g., on Windows, use !dir instead of !ls) to ensure you can run and inspect outputs in the notebook.

answer_llm:
- ML part: you only need a working laptop with an internet connection.
- Deep Learning part: more resource-intensive; you can use cloud services (e.g., Saturn Cloud or any other cloud).
- Free / cloud options: AWS and GCP offer free micro-instances for a long time; Saturn provides free GPU hours (promo available via ML Zoomcamp). For even easier setup, small AWS instances can be run for free, though larger ones incur costs.

question: Is there a guide to set up TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
- You need CUDA and cuDNN to run TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu. Install Nvidia drivers first, then CUDA and cuDNN, and finally TensorFlow with GPU support.

What to do (based on the course materials):
- Install Nvidia drivers: https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx
- Linux/TensorFlow installation path: Install TensorFlow with pip (Linux)
  - https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1
  - Make sure to follow the guidance to install CUDA by environment (as indicated in the guide)
- Install CUDA toolkit: https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive (choose an 11.x.x series as referenced)
- Install cuDNN: https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download
- Optional: follow the course-referenced simplified guide for Ubuntu setup: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/
- After completing these steps, you should be able to train/infer with GPU in TensorFlow.

Note (optional troubleshooting): If you encounter GPU memory allocation issues, you can try enabling memory growth in TensorFlow as described in the course notes:
- Configuring memory growth: set config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True in a TensorFlow session.
answer_orig: Here is an article that worked for me: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/
question: How do I configure GPU support for TensorFlow on my Ubuntu machine?

answer_orig: Here is an article that worked for me: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/
question: Can you direct me to a resource for installing TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
Based on the CONTEXT, the procedure to set up TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu involves installing NVIDIA drivers and the CUDA/cuDNN stack, then installing TensorFlow for Linux. A linked article is also provided that allegedly worked for someone.

Steps (as described in the CONTEXT):
- Install NVIDIA drivers: https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx
- On Linux/Ubuntu, install TensorFlow using the Linux path (pip): https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1
- Make sure to follow step 4 to install CUDA by environment (as referenced in the Linux install guide), including exporting XLA-related environment settings, e.g. an environment variable like XLA_FLAGS to point to the CUDA data directory in your environment.
- Install CUDA Toolkit version 11.x.x: https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive
- Install cuDNN: https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download
- After these installations, you should be able to train/infer with GPU in TensorFlow.

Additionally, there is a specific article that reportedly worked for someone: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/
answer_orig: Here is an article that worked for me: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/

Here’s how to join a channel in Slack:

- Click “All channels” at the top of your left sidebar. If you don’t see this option, click “More” to find it.
- Browse the list of public channels in your workspace, or use the search bar to search by channel name or description.
- Select a channel from the list to view it.
- Click “Join Channel.”

For reference, you can also view the official guide here: https://slack.com/help/articles/205239967-Join-a-channel

question: How can I join a channel in Slack?

answer_llm:
Here are the steps to find and join course channels in Slack:

- Open Slack and click “All channels” at the top of your left sidebar. If you don’t see it, click “More” to find it.
- Browse the list of public channels in your workspace, or use the search bar to search by channel name or description.
- Click a channel from the list to view it.
- Click “Join Channel” to join.

Optional: To stay updated for this course, you can join the specific course channel, e.g., #course-ml-zoomcamp.

If you’d like a quick reference, you can also view Slack’s guide on joining a channel here: https://slack.com/help/articles/205239967-Join-a-channel.

answer_llm: Yes. You can join the course after it has started and participate. You may not be able to submit some of the homeworks. For example, joining at the end of November and completing two projects would still make you eligible for a certificate.
